content: The policy's been this way as far back as I can remember it. The military is rather serious about firearms. We are not allowed to call them guns. We are indoctrinated within hours of arriving at Reception/Recruit depot that they are WEAPONS and their main purpose is TO KILL OTHER HUMAN BEINGS. There is none of this politically nice sounding "self-defense" talk, which sort of beats around the bush about the fact that the weapon is designed to kill. Then comes long lessons on muzzle awareness, safety, clearing weapons properly, NEVER leaving them unattended, proper arms room protocol, etc. It's the profession of arms. There are necessarily very strict rules. All weapons must be secured, at all times. Even bows and arrows and largish daggers. This means A) you have it strapped to your chest/side (and on duty that does NOT include POWs), or B) it is in a military-rated arms rooms. There's equally strict rules about storing and guarding ammunition. The only place a servicemember is free to walk around freely with weapon and live ammo is in a COMBAT ZONE. We don't have very many rights as long as we serve. We have a lot of responsibilities, though. Mainly to grant folks back home the freedom to not professionally bear arms if they so choose, and to join freedom colonies in New Hampshire, if that's their thing. Enjoy your civilianhood, SFC in Bliss.

content: The policy's been this way as far back as I can remember it. The military is rather serious about firearms. We are not allowed to call them guns. We are indoctrinated within hours of arriving at Reception/Recruit depot that they are WEAPONS and their main purpose is TO KILL OTHER HUMAN BEINGS. There is none of this politically nice sounding "self-defense" talk, which sort of beats around the bush about the fact that the weapon is designed to kill. Then comes long lessons on muzzle awareness, safety, clearing weapons properly, NEVER leaving them unattended, proper arms room protocol, etc. It's the profession of arms. There are necessarily very strict rules. All weapons must be secured, at all times. Even bows and arrows and largish daggers. This means A) you have it strapped to your chest/side (and on duty that does NOT include POWs), or B) it is in a military-rated arms rooms. There's equally strict rules about storing and guarding ammunition. The only place a servicemember is free to walk around freely with weapon and live ammo is in a COMBAT ZONE. We don't have very many rights as long as we serve. We have a lot of responsibilities, though. Mainly to grant folks back home the freedom to not professionally bear arms if they so choose, and to join freedom colonies in New Hampshire, if that's their thing. Enjoy your civilianhood, SFC in Bliss.
